column10: Explanation

column1: Who's responsible for Gantt Charts in Scrum?
column10: Gantt Chart is not a Scrum artifact and not compatible with the framework.

column1: Which statements are correct about Product Backlog refinement? (Choose 2 answers)
column3: It should be done right before the Sprint Planning
column4: The Scrum Master should facilitate it
column5: It shouldn't take more than 10% of the Development Team's time
column10:
If multiple teams are working on the project, they will participate in the refinement as well. Refinement can take any amount of time from the Product Owner but not more than 10% of the capacity of the Development Team.

Refinement is a continuous activity not limited to a certain time during the Sprint. The Scrum Master only facilitates the meetings as requested or required; not by default.

column1: The Product Owner has doubts about the quality of the definition of "Done". What should s/he do?
column4: Adjust the definition of "Done" at the end of the Sprint
column5: Ask the company QA department to investigate the issue
column6: Point it out in the next Sprint Retrospective
column10: The Development Team is responsible for the definition of "Done" rather than the Product Owner. So, if the Product Owner doubts the quality of the definition of "Done", he/she can discuss it with the team on the next Sprint Retrospective, so that if they agree, it would be adjusted for the next Sprint.

column1: How long does the Sprint Planning take in a project with three-week Sprints?
column10: Sprint Planning is 8 hours for a one-month Sprint and usually shorter proportionally for shorter Sprints.

column1: Which Scrum artifacts are ordered?
column5: Both the Product Backlog and Sprint Backlog
column10:
The Product Backlog is ordered (prioritized) based on the business value.

The items in the Sprint Backlog follow the same order they had in the Product Backlog, therefore, are prioritized.

column1: Which of the following describe the definition of "Done"? (choose 2 answers)
column6: Helps ensure the Increment is releasable
column10: Definition of "Done" increases transparency because everyone knows what it means by "Done". It includes everything required for creating something usable by the end users (potentially releasable).

column1: Pick 4 activities that are the responsibility of the Development Team.
column5: Break down epic user stories into smaller ones
column10: Designing the software is part of the development and should be done by the developers. They are self-organized and make technical decisions and volunteer for tasks (assign them to themselves). Estimation is the responsibility of the developers because they are the people who will develop the item.

column1: Which of the following is a valid service from the Scrum Master to the Product Owner?
column3: Helping the Product Owner find techniques for managing the Product Backlog.
column4: Act as a proxy when the Product Owner is not available to the team.
column5: Helping the Product Owner order the Product Backlog items in order to maximize value.
column6: Act as the middleman between the Product Owner and the Development Team, as requested or required

column1: When does inspection occur?
column3: When the Product Owner finds necessary
column4: Frequently, but not so often that gets in the way of work.
column10:
All Scrum events are opportunities for inspection and adaptation.

Inspection makes adaptation possible and that's why it's important. However, like anything else in Agile, we just like to have "enough" of it.

column1: When is it time for integrating the solution?
column4: At the end of the Sprint
column6: At the end of the project
column10: Integration is part of the development of each item and a step in a normal definition of "Done". Agile projects use continuous integration to make the output potentially releasable.

column1: Which role is responsible for managing the Development Team?
column10: The Development Team is self-organized and manages itself instead of receiving orders.

column1: The Sprint Backlog makes visible all of the work the ... identifies as necessary to meet the Sprint Goal.
column10:
This is up to the developers to identify how to accomplish the goal. After all, they are the technical people in the project.

The question is about the Sprint Backlog tasks, rather than items.

column1: Who monitors the remaining work of the Product Backlog?
column10:
The Product Owner is responsible for measuring the progress of the project and tracking the remaining work in the Product Backlog.

The Development Team is responsible for measuring the progress of the Sprint and tracking the remaining work in the Sprint Backlog.

column1: Who can change the Sprint Backlog in the middle of the Sprint?
column10: he Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint do not change but the Sprint Backlog also contains tasks and tasks evolve through the Sprint. The Development Team owns the Sprint Backlog and only they can change the Sprint Backlog. This is sometimes done based on the input from the Product Owner.

column1: What type of process control is Scrum?
column10: Scrum is empirical; based on the real-world experiences.

column1: Who assigns tasks to the developers?
column10: The developers take responsibility for doing the tasks themselves and the Development Team ensures that all tasks are done properly. Remember that they are self-organized. When items are "Done", the Product Owner checked them but this is focused on the item rather than individuals; all developers are accountable for the team's outputs.

column1: How should developers deal with non-functional features?
column5: Incorporate them in the hardening Sprint
column6: Incorporate them in the integration Sprint
column10:
Non-functional features are usually part of the Definition of Done and should be considered for every Product Backlog item and every Increment. Sometime, some non-functional features that address a very particular part of the software can be added as separate items in the Product Backlog.

All Sprints are the same. There's no Sprint zero, hardening Sprint, release Sprint, integration Sprint, etc.

column1: Which of the following is a prerequisite for starting the Sprint Planning meeting?
column3: Having the Product Backlog items cleared and assigned to developers
column4: Having the items at the top of the Product Backlog small enough to fit in one Sprint
column5: Having the requirements specified and completely reflected in the Product Backlog
column10:
We prefer to have "ready" items at the top of the Product Backlog before Sprint Planning, which is done through Product Backlog refinement. However, nothing stops our flow of Sprints. For example, we do not delay the Sprint because the items are not ready. In such cases, the "unready" items would be selected for the Sprint and refined during the Sprint.

"Ready" items are those that are clear and small enough to fit into one Sprint.

column1: Which of the following refers to the average amount of work done per Sprint?
column10: Velocity is the amount of work (usually in "story points") done per Sprint. For example, 200 story points per Sprint.

column1: Who owns the Sprint Backlog?
column10: The Development Team owns the Sprint Backlog and the Product Owner owns the Product Backlog.
